document.masterDocTitle: Seven new species of the leafhopper genus Tambocerus (Hemiptera: Cicadellidae) from the Indian subcontinent

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Seven new species of the leafhopper genus Tambocerus (Hemiptera: Cicadellidae) from the Indian subcontinent

paragraph.keyLead:
1. Male subgenital plates rather quadrate ( Figs 60–62 ); caudal lobe of pygofer with ventral dark pigmented crest ( Figs 57–59 )........................................................................................
T. krameri
sp. nov.

2. Pygofer caudal lobe with dorsal and ventral dark pigmented crests ( Fig. 86 ); aedeagal shaft in posterior view constricted abruptly near apex ( Figs 92, 93 )...........................................................
T. viraktamathi Rao

– Pygofer caudal lobe without dark pigmented crests ( Figs 32 , 40 ); aedeagal shaft in posterior view not constricted abruptly near apex................................................................................................ 3

keyLead.keyStep: 5. Pygofer lobe either constricted in distal region ( Figs 24 , 95 ) or narrowed in lateral view ( Fig. 32 )...................... 6

paragraph.keyLead:
6. Aedeagus with atrium ventrally produced ( Fig. 38 ); shaft of uniform width in posterior view ( Fig. 39 ).....
T. cholas
sp. nov.
- Aedeagus with atrium not ventrally produced ( Figs 29 , 100 ); shaft narrowed distally in posterior view ( Figs 30 , 99 )....... 7

7. Aedeagal shaft with basal triangular ventral process in lateral view ( Fig. 29 ); shaft broader in basal half then narrowed distally in posterior view ( Figs 30 ).................................................................
T. acutus
sp. nov.

– Aedeagal shaft lacking triangular ventral process in lateral view ( Fig. 100 ); shaft in middle almost parallel sided ( Fig. 99 ).........................................................................................
T. zahniseri
sp. nov.

- Forewing lacking brown maculations ( Figs 18–20 ); male pygofer mesally produced near apex ( Figs 77, 78 )
T. nilgiris
sp. nov.

9. Aedeagal shaft curved dorsally near apical 0.33 length, lateral serrations on shaft extend to distal 0.75 length, shaft of uniform width in posterior view ( Zhang & Webb 1996 , Figs 92–93 )..................................
T. disparatus (Melichar)

- Aedeagal shaft straight, lateral serrations confined to apical 0.25 length, shaft broad at basal 0.75, then narrowed ( Zhang & Webb 1996 , Figs 94 , 97 )................................................................
T. plumbeus (Distant)
